title: Bio
text:
Allison Koh is a Research Fellow in Natural Language Processing at the University of Birmingham’s Centre for Artificial Intelligence in Government. She is a computational political scientist working at the intersection of international relations, political communication, and computational methods. The substantive foci of her work are the geopolitics of emerging technologies and applications of generative AI in conflict research. Her ongoing research examines the strategic landscape of digital transnational repression on social media, the state-aligned online harassment of diaspora activists, and the effect of Twitter’s recent policy changes on the influence of government and state-affiliated media accounts. Koh holds a PhD in Political Science and MPP in Policy Analysis from the Hertie School in Berlin, and completed her BSc in Economics and Asian Studies at Tulane University.

title: Allison Koh | Computational Political Scientist
text:
Allison Koh | Computational Political Scientist

I am a Research Fellow in Natural Language Processing at the University of Birmingham’s Centre for Artificial Intelligence in Government.
My research interests lie at the intersection of international relations, political communication, and computational social science. The substantive foci of my work are the geopolitics of emerging technologies and applications of generative AI in conflict research. In my dissertation, I collected millions of tweets to analyze how vulnerabilities in social media companies’ platforms and policies can benefit the foreign policy interests of authoritarian regimes.
I recently earned my PhD at the Hertie School’s Centre for International Security in Berlin. I also hold an MPP in Policy Analysis from the Hertie School and a BSc in Economics and Asian Studies from Tulane University.
I’m from Queens, New York and am currently based in London.
